nodes.bodyText: Next up: fix https://github.com/OpenAdaptAI/OpenAdapt/actions/runs/6045965552/job/16406784298#step:4:543

Thank you @KrishPatel13 !
It's a bit verbose. Why not use getenv_fallback?
I asked ChatGPT for input here: https://chat.openai.com/share/7ddeca53-1174-4686-b82d-0ad305d2d1d3 :

For managing configuration in a Python project more elegantly, while avoiding repetitive code, you can use libraries like pydantic, environs, or python-decouple. Each of these offers unique features and simplifies the process of handling environment variables and configuration settings. Here's a brief overview of each approach:
1. Pydantic
Pydantic is known for its data validation using Python type annotations. It can be especially useful for loading and validating configurations.

Define a configuration model using Pydantic classes.
Set default values and types directly in the class definition.
Load and validate environment variables automatically.

Example:
from pydantic import BaseModel, Field
from typing import Optional

class Config(BaseModel):
    cache_dir_path: str = Field(default=".cache")
    cache_enabled: bool = Field(default=True)
    cache_verbosity: int = Field(default=0)
    db_echo: bool = Field(default=False)
    db_fname: str = Field(default="openadapt.db")

config = Config(_env_file='.env')
2. Environs
Environs is a library that wraps around marshmallow to provide simple environment variable parsing.

Define schema for your environment variables.
Use methods to cast variables to the correct type.
Can handle complex data types and validation.

Example:
from environs import Env

env = Env()
env.read_env()  # read .env file, if it exists

# Define variables with type casting
cache_dir_path = env.str("CACHE_DIR_PATH", ".cache")
cache_enabled = env.bool("CACHE_ENABLED", True)
cache_verbosity = env.int("CACHE_VERBOSITY", 0)
db_echo = env.bool("DB_ECHO", False)
db_fname = env.str("DB_FNAME", "openadapt.db")
3. Python-Decouple
Python-Decouple is focused on separating settings from code, which is useful for 12-factor applications.

Simple API for accessing environment variables.
Supports type casting and default values.
Clean and straightforward for basic needs.

Example:
from decouple import config

CACHE_DIR_PATH = config('CACHE_DIR_PATH', default='.cache')
CACHE_ENABLED = config('CACHE_ENABLED', cast=bool, default=True)
CACHE_VERBOSITY = config('CACHE_VERBOSITY', cast=int, default=0)
DB_ECHO = config('DB_ECHO', cast=bool, default=False)
DB_FNAME = config('DB_FNAME', default='openadapt.db')
Choosing the Right Tool

Pydantic: Best for complex configurations with a need for strict type validation.
Environs: Useful for more complex data types and custom validation logic.
Python-Decouple: Ideal for simpler use cases where the primary goal is to separate configuration from code.

Each of these libraries reduces the repetitive nature of environment variable management and adds the benefit of type checking and validation, making your configuration management both more elegant and robust.

Since we are already using Pydantic in https://github.com/OpenAdaptAI/OpenAdapt/blob/main/openadapt/privacy/base.py#L6 I think it makes sense to re-use it here. What do you think?
Closing this in favor of a future PR which uses Pydantic.

node.title: feat: 404 page in place
node.body:
Fixes: [CDEP-2255](https://tegel.atlassian.net/jira/software/projects/CDEP/boards/1?assignee=63ff6d6c314f5088138187f0&selectedIssue=CDEP-2255)

**How to test:**
Go to a page that does not exist, easiest by mispelling a url, for example: https://deploy-preview-51--tegel-angular-demo.netlify.app/steppers

Design for it:
https://www.figma.com/file/0qInyxtj8DZ6thDesNat5M/Empty-screens-exploration?type=design&node-id=81-83069&mode=design&t=CfZIYa7YXq8H6fR7-4

Getting some unexpected overflow. Suspecting it might have to do with the 100vh being set on the error page. Would be better if it only takes 100% and with a flex-grow: 1.
Expected behaviour: The error page content should take as much space at it can, without creating an overflow.


That is doable, however will yield basically this look:

Expected behaviour: The error page content should take as much space at it can, without creating an overflow.


That is doable, however will yield basically this look:


Height and display would have to be adjusted on the app-error-page element, as well as a few parent elements of it to achieve the desired height.

VH might be good enough for now considering there are a lot of other implementations that could be better as well.
Unless we want to demonstrate a proper way of doing things - Is that a purpose of this repo?

Another possible improvement would be to not redirect to 404, and just show the 404 page if the route does not exist.
Like that: https://angular.io/guide/router-tutorial#adding-a-404-page
This is how they suggest it in the angular docs above - and is not a more complicated way of doing things. I feel like its better UX to stay on the route to show that it doesn't exist.

node.title: Added support for Swarm Mode
node.body:
### Description

Added support for Swarm Mode which starts the necessary processes in order to be part of the Petals Swarm. The User can `Enable` the mode from Settings. Tauri will spawn a thread that installs the dependencies and runs the python process.

The PR contains all the building blocks in order to implement the complete POC functionality.

### Limitations

- UI/UX must be drastically improved. No CSS changes have been made.
- It currently works only if the User has Python installed on its machine.

@tiero @casperdcl @sekulicd @Janaka-Steph please have a look.

nodes.bodyText:
PR Summary


Introduction of a checking mechanism for Python
A new functionality is added to verify that Python is correctly installed on the machine.


Enhanced support for Swarm Mode
New functions have been introduced to allow for better handling of Docker's Swarm Mode. Specifically, these functions enable us to check the running status of Swarm Mode, start it, and stop it when needed.


Addition of SwarmMode Component
A new component named SwarmMode is created to incorporate Docker's Swarm Mode features into our application UI. This component is added as part of our Settings module, empowering users with more operational flexibility.


Utilities for Swarm Mode
Additional utility functions for handling Docker Swarm Mode are implemented. These help us to verify the operational status of Swarm Mode, stop it, or start it based on user input or application requirements.

node.bodyText: can't we allow anything on $PATH instead? (Same for all /usr/bin hardcoded below)
Potentially fallback to pip install --user before giving up?
Won't this potentially pick up unrelated multiprocessing tasks?
kill -n 15 or kill -n 9?
LGTM
It will not work with Tauri. We had that issue in the past.
Ideally, we should install python, conda, create a conda env, and then install, but I want your opinion on that on how to make this installation super smooth.

Yep, there is that risk, but I don't know how to get that otherwise. Not critical for a POC / Demo.
85485 ttys038    0:00.03 /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/Library/Frameworks/Python3.framework/Versions/3.9/Resources/Python.app/Contents/MacOS/Python -c from multiprocessing.resource_tracker import main;main(12)
I checked this and by default kill uses -n 15 which seems to work nicely in this context. While trying with kill -n 9 processes are not properly killed.

try to find mamba on $PATH
try to find conda on $PATH
try to find python3 on $PATH
